page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 55: Line 55:
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
â
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Torchia, Christopher|title=AP Interview: Egypt Declares Treasures Safe|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST_ANTIQUITIES?SITE=TNKNN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'')|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref>
+
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110201/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt_protest_antiquities</ref>
ElBaradei's detention prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01" /> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1" /> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2" />
ElBaradei's detention prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01" /> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1" /> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2" />
Line 109: Line 109:
{{quote|"The armed forces will not resort to use of force against our great people. Your armed forces, who are aware of the legitimacy of your demands and are keen to assume their responsibility in protecting the nation and the citizens, affirms that freedom of expression through peaceful means is guaranteed to everybody."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Nakhoul|first=Samia|title=Update 1 â Egypt Army: Will Not Use Violence Against Citizens|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70U2JC20110131|work=[[Reuters]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>}}
{{quote|"The armed forces will not resort to use of force against our great people. Your armed forces, who are aware of the legitimacy of your demands and are keen to assume their responsibility in protecting the nation and the citizens, affirms that freedom of expression through peaceful means is guaranteed to everybody."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Nakhoul|first=Samia|title=Update 1 â Egypt Army: Will Not Use Violence Against Citizens|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70U2JC20110131|work=[[Reuters]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>}}
â
Reports emerged of several major prisons across the country being attacked, and law and order rapidly deteriorated across most of Egypt.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html ''Al Jazeera English'' coverage of events].</ref> Criminal violence continued in Cairo as looters burnt out the Arkadia shopping mall. [[Egypt Air]] cancelled all internal and outbound flights;<ref name="aljazeera1" /><ref name="wilsherline.net.uk">[http://www.wilsherline.net.uk/ "Egypt Air cancels all flights"]</ref> an inbound Egypt Air flight from London to Cairo was diverted to [[Athens]] because of an alleged bomb threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/egyptair-jet-diverted-to-athens-after-bomb-scare-53824639.html|title=EgyptAir Jet Diverted to Athens after Bomb Scare |publisher=Comparecarhire.co.uk|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
+
Reports emerged of several major prisons across the country being attacked, and law and order rapidly deteriorated across most of Egypt.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html ''Al Jazeera English'' coverage of events].</ref> Criminal violence continued in Cairo as looters burnt out the Arkadia shopping mall. [[Egypt Air]] cancelled all internal and outbound flights;<ref name="aljazeera1" /><ref name="EgyptAir cancels flights overnight on Tuesday">http://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFJOE70U0FF20110131</ref> an inbound Egypt Air flight from London to Cairo was diverted to [[Athens]] because of an alleged bomb threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/egyptair-jet-diverted-to-athens-after-bomb-scare-53824639.html|title=EgyptAir Jet Diverted to Athens after Bomb Scare |publisher=Comparecarhire.co.uk|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Industrial strikes were also called in many cities, including Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelondondailynews.com/lets-cheer-democracy-egypt-p-5046.html |title=Lets cheer for democracy in Egypt?|publisher=The London Daily News |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> [[Nissan]] had suspended production at its plant in Egypt to ensure employees' safety after anti-government protests, but [[Hyundai]]'s plant chose to continue working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-suspends-production-at-giza-plant_id108821.aspx|title=Egypt: Nissan Suspends Production at Giza Plant: Automotive News & Analysis|publisher=Just-auto.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Industrial strikes were also called in many cities, including Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelondondailynews.com/lets-cheer-democracy-egypt-p-5046.html |title=Lets cheer for democracy in Egypt?|publisher=The London Daily News |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> [[Nissan]] had suspended production at its plant in Egypt to ensure employees' safety after anti-government protests, but [[Hyundai]]'s plant chose to continue working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-suspends-production-at-giza-plant_id108821.aspx|title=Egypt: Nissan Suspends Production at Giza Plant: Automotive News & Analysis|publisher=Just-auto.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 127: Line 127:
Similar protests occurred across Egypt with hundreds of thousands in Alexandria, and an estimated 250,000 in Sinai<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112113115442982.html|title=Protesters Flood Egypt Streets|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/01/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests â Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> and [[Suez]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Aneja, Atul|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/02/stories/2011020263100100.htm |title=Unprecedented Show of People Power at Egypt's Tahrir Square |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> marking the largest mobilisation in the then eight day old protest. Meanwhile, a virtual "March of Millions" was launched on [[Facebook]] with the goal of reaching one million voices in support of the march.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=126197157451259|title=Niet Compatibele Browser|publisher=[[Facebook]]|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Similar protests occurred across Egypt with hundreds of thousands in Alexandria, and an estimated 250,000 in Sinai<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112113115442982.html|title=Protesters Flood Egypt Streets|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/01/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests â Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> and [[Suez]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Aneja, Atul|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/02/stories/2011020263100100.htm |title=Unprecedented Show of People Power at Egypt's Tahrir Square |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> marking the largest mobilisation in the then eight day old protest. Meanwhile, a virtual "March of Millions" was launched on [[Facebook]] with the goal of reaching one million voices in support of the march.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=126197157451259|title=Niet Compatibele Browser|publisher=[[Facebook]]|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money and prices skyrocketed as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister, urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money and prices skyrocketed as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-food-inflation-by-day-roaming-looters-at-night.html</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister, urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
In the late evening (11:00 PM local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". He called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the term limits of the presidency and to change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against parliament members which meant a great amount of the parliament members would be changed through the legal process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text â President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
In the late evening (11:00 PM local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". He called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the term limits of the presidency and to change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against parliament members which meant a great amount of the parliament members would be changed through the legal process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text â President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 207: Line 207:
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|left|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|left|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]
â
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Army-seeks-to-free-Tahrir-Square-for-traffic/articleshow/7433560.cms |title=Army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher=Times of India |date=Feb 5, 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
+
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
â
State television announced the appointment of [[Hossam Badrawi]] ''(seen as a member of the liberal wing of the party)''<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" /> as Head of the Shura Council after [[Safwat El-Sherif]]'s resignation from his position within the party. Mubarak's son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] also resigned as Assistant Secretary and Secretary of the Policy Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/05/136363.html |title=Ø¥ÙØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù.. ÙØªØ¹ÙÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø§ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙÙØ§ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Minister of State for Legal Affairs Mufid Shehab and Presidential Chief-of-Staff [[Zakaria Azmy]] were dismissed from the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310041 |title=NDP overhaul a meager concession, says opposition | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Initial reports indicated that Mubarak had resigned as head of the ruling NDP party,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dowling |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/mubarak-focuses-on-economic-issues-as-protests-continue-2011-02/ |title=Protests continue in Egypt as NDP leadership resigns Â· TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> however this was later denied by state television and the Information Minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hossam Badrawi replaces NDP's Secretary general Safwat El Sherif and Gamal Mubarak|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/5039.aspx|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=5 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Information Minister denies Mubarak's resignation from ruling party|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311088|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> Former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli and three of his leadership were put under house arrest. There had been reports about the arrest of other security leaders who were being held in a military prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptâs-attorney-general-bans-former-ministers-and-officials-travel|title=Egyptâs attorney-general bans former ministers and officials from travel|publisherAlmasry Alyoum|date= |accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, the opposition leaders continued to seek ways to remove Mubarak from power. They called on the protesters to continue at Tahrir Square every Tuesday and Friday until Mubarak "resigns and makes true the demands of the people."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" />
+
State television announced the appointment of [[Hossam Badrawi]] ''(seen as a member of the liberal wing of the party)''<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" /> as Head of the Shura Council after [[Safwat El-Sherif]]'s resignation from his position within the party. Mubarak's son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] also resigned as Assistant Secretary and Secretary of the Policy Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/05/136363.html |title=Ø¥ÙØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù.. ÙØªØ¹ÙÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø§ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙÙØ§ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Minister of State for Legal Affairs Mufid Shehab and Presidential Chief-of-Staff [[Zakaria Azmy]] were dismissed from the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310041 |title=NDP overhaul a meager concession, says opposition | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Initial reports indicated that Mubarak had resigned as head of the ruling NDP party,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dowling |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/mubarak-focuses-on-economic-issues-as-protests-continue-2011-02/ |title=Protests continue in Egypt as NDP leadership resigns Â· TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> however this was later denied by state television and the Information Minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hossam Badrawi replaces NDP's Secretary general Safwat El Sherif and Gamal Mubarak|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/5039.aspx|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=5 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Information Minister denies Mubarak's resignation from ruling party|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311088|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> Former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli and three of his leadership were put under house arrest. There had been reports about the arrest of other security leaders who were being held in a military prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/308543|title=Egyptâs attorney-general bans former ministers and officials from travel|publisherAlmasry Alyoum|date= |accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, the opposition leaders continued to seek ways to remove Mubarak from power. They called on the protesters to continue at Tahrir Square every Tuesday and Friday until Mubarak "resigns and makes true the demands of the people."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" />
Trouble hit the border city of [[Rafah|Rafa]] as a grenade was tossed into an empty church and the public library was set on fire on February 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/story_print.html?id=4231180&sponsor=|title=Militants blow up Egypt gas pipeline|publisher=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-02-08|accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref>
Trouble hit the border city of [[Rafah|Rafa]] as a grenade was tossed into an empty church and the public library was set on fire on February 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/story_print.html?id=4231180&sponsor=|title=Militants blow up Egypt gas pipeline|publisher=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-02-08|accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref>

===10 February===
===10 February===
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
â
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of Mubarak's official residences. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued and spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> Protesters around Egypt, expecting Mubarak's resignation, were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>({{citation|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iEz31PZvDAAwis44KBhmha7EBxZw?docId=947212c1ab074fbe9513c7f6791a339a|title=Expecting Mubarak to go, protest camp euphoric|publisher=AFP}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of Mubarak's official residences. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued and spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> Protesters around Egypt, expecting Mubarak's resignation, were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110210/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt_protest_scene_1</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. The head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" />
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. The head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" />
Line 287: Line 287:
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name=transfers/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September |publisher=Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Suleiman called on the protesters to go home.<ref name=transfers>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> ElBaradei said, "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name=transfers/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September |publisher=Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Suleiman called on the protesters to go home.<ref name=transfers>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> ElBaradei said, "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>

Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could ride out the turmoil, which convinced him to cling to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that one son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/22/20110213/tpl-uk-egypt-mubarak-sons-4b8df73.html |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows - report - Yahoo! News UK |publisher=Uk.news.yahoo.com |date=2010-01-01 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/315254 |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
+
Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could ride out the turmoil, which convinced him to cling to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that one son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/13/us-egypt-mubarak-sons-idUSTRE71C26L20110213</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/315254 |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
===11 February===
===11 February===
Line 305: Line 305:
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/> ElBaradei told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expected a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the Iranian [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/> ElBaradei told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expected a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the Iranian [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
â
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-year [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and dissolve parliament.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebrations and car honking were reported in Alexandria and Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebratory gunfire in Gaza.<ref>{{cite web|last=Karam |first=Zeina |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/breakingnews/israeli-officials-say-egypts-mubarak-is-looking-for-an-honourable-exit-from-power-115849349.html |title=With fireworks and celebratory gunfire, festivities sweep Mideast after news of Mubarak's exit |publisher=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
+
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-year [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and dissolve parliament.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebrations and car honking were reported in Alexandria and Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebratory gunfire in Gaza.<ref>http://ca.news.yahoo.com/israeli-officials-egypts-mubarak-looking-honourable-exit-power-20110211-000625-393.html</ref>
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
